text: Namibia is expected to compete at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Originally scheduled to take place from 24 July to 9 August 2020, the Games have been postponed to 23 July to 8 August 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be the nation's eighth consecutive appearance at the Summer Olympics. ==Athletics== Namibian athletes achieved the entry standards, either by qualifying time or by world ranking, in the following track and field events (up to a maximum of 3 athletes in each event): ;Track & road events {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Result !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Helalia Johannes |align=left|Women's marathon | | |} ==Boxing== Namibia entered one boxer into the Olympic tournament. Rio 2016 Olympian Jonas Junius scored an outright semifinal victory to secure a spot in the men's lightweight division at the 2020 African Qualification Tournament in Diamniadio, Senegal. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !Round of 32 !Round of 16 !Quarterfinals !Semifinals !colspan=2|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Jonas Junius |align=left|Men's lightweight | | | | | | |} ==Cycling== ===Road=== Namibia entered one rider to compete in the men's Olympic road race, by finishing in the top two, not yet qualified, at the 2019 African Championships in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. An additional spot was awarded to a Namibian cyclist in the women's road race by virtue of a top 100 individual finish in the UCI World Ranking. {|class=wikitable style=font-size:90%;text-align:center |- !Athlete !Event !Time !Rank |- |align=left| |align=left|Men's road race | | |- |align=left| |align=left|Women's road race | | |} ==Rowing== Namibia qualified one boat in the women's single sculls for the Games by winning the gold medal and securing the first of five berths available at the 2019 FISA African Olympic Qualification Regatta in Tunis, Tunisia, marking the country's debut in the sport. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Heats !colspan="2"|Repechage !colspan="2"|Quarterfinals !colspan="2"|Semifinals !colspan="2"|Final |- style="font-size:95%" !Time !Rank !Time !Rank !Time !Rank !Time !Rank !Time !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Maike Diekmann |align=left|Women's single sculls | | | | | | | | | | |} Qualification Legend: FA=Final A (medal); FB=Final B (non-medal); FC=Final C (non-medal); FD=Final D (non-medal); FE=Final E (non-medal); FF=Final F (non-medal); SA/B=Semifinals A/B; SC/D=Semifinals C/D; SE/F=Semifinals E/F; QF=Quarterfinals; R=Repechage ==See also== *Namibia at the 2020 Summer Paralympics ==References== Category:Nations at the 2020 Summer Olympics 2020 Category:2021 in Namibian sport
title: Namibia at the 2020 Summer Olympics
